description: Adding a virial validation check onto the clump finder. This should augment the current the gravitationally bound check.
title: Adding Virial validation from Bleuler & Tessier (2014)

content.html: Couldn't you just use _virial_validation directly?

pullrequest.title: Adding Virial validation from Bleuler & Tessier (2014)

content.raw:
Hey sorry, so I was saying you don't need the `_virial_check` function at all, instead you should have:

```
add_validator("virial_check", _virial_validation)
```

And then delete `_virial_check`
content.html:
Hey sorry, so I was saying you don't need the _virial_check function at all, instead you should have:

add_validator("virial_check", _virial_validation)

And then delete _virial_check

pullrequest.title: Adding Virial validation from Bleuler & Tessier (2014)

```
#!C

use_particles
```
 still be used?
content.html:

still be used?

content.raw: Yes, because `_virial_validation` has the same signature as `_virial_check`.
content.html: Yes, because _virial_validation has the same signature as _virial_check.

pullrequest.title: Adding Virial validation from Bleuler & Tessier (2014)

content.raw:
flake8 is complaining because you assign to the `grad_fields` name but then don't use it later. Instead you should just do:

```
if use_particles:
    self.data_source.ds.add_gradient_fields(("all","gravitational_potential"))
```

Hope that makes sense. There are a few other places that might need to be touched up as well. You can run flake8 locally by installing it from pip, then running it inside the repository:

```
$ pip install flake8
$ cd $YT_REPO
$ flake8 ./yt
```
content.html:
flake8 is complaining because you assign to the grad_fields name but then don't use it later. Instead you should just do:

if use_particles:
    self.data_source.ds.add_gradient_fields(("all","gravitational_potential"))

Hope that makes sense. There are a few other places that might need to be touched up as well. You can run flake8 locally by installing it from pip, then running it inside the repository:

$ pip install flake8
$ cd $YT_REPO
$ flake8 ./yt

pullrequest.title: Adding Virial validation from Bleuler & Tessier (2014)

content.raw:
We prefer non-relative imports in yt:

```
from yt.analysis_modules.level_sets.virial_validator import _virial_validation
```
content.html:
We prefer non-relative imports in yt:

from yt.analysis_modules.level_sets.virial_validator import _virial_validation

pullrequest.title: Adding Virial validation from Bleuler & Tessier (2014)

content.raw: I don't see any obvious code problems, but I had a brief comment.  The surface object can also sample and compute flux; I am trying to piece together whether that can be made to be identical to your computation, as it should happen all inline with the calculation of triangles and could be faster.  That isn't a show stopper, but it would reduce the number of places in the code that it's necessary.  Otherwise, I am +1 on this.  Thanks, @john_regan !
content.html: I don't see any obvious code problems, but I had a brief comment. The surface object can also sample and compute flux; I am trying to piece together whether that can be made to be identical to your computation, as it should happen all inline with the calculation of triangles and could be faster. That isn't a show stopper, but it would reduce the number of places in the code that it's necessary. Otherwise, I am +1 on this. Thanks, John Regan !

pullrequest.title: Adding Virial validation from Bleuler & Tessier (2014)

content.raw: Why is this necessary? I think surf["pressure"] will already have units attached. If a user has selected a non-CGS unit system, this will also (I think) force the units to be `dyne/cm**2` even if the numerical data aren't in that unit.
content.html: Why is this necessary? I think surf["pressure"] will already have units attached. If a user has selected a non-CGS unit system, this will also (I think) force the units to be dyne/cm**2 even if the numerical data aren't in that unit.

pullrequest.title: Adding Virial validation from Bleuler & Tessier (2014)

content.raw: again, here, I think these two lines should be `clump.data.quantities.center_of_mass().in_units('code_length')`. The way you have it now, you're stripping the units and assuming that the center of mass will always be in `code_length` which i don't think is true.
content.html: again, here, I think these two lines should be clump.data.quantities.center_of_mass().in_units('code_length'). The way you have it now, you're stripping the units and assuming that the center of mass will always be in code_length which i don't think is true.

pullrequest.title: Adding Virial validation from Bleuler & Tessier (2014)

content.raw: same issue here, convert to 'cm', don't assume the positions are in CGS.
content.html: same issue here, convert to 'cm', don't assume the positions are in CGS.

content.raw: Hi @MatthewTurk, I think I tried to get the surface object to do the fluxes but couldn't get it to work. It's a few months ago now though so I can't remember exactly what the issue was. I'll update the issues that @ngoldbaum pointed out and re-submit the PR along with a test.
content.html: Hi Matt Turk, I think I tried to get the surface object to do the fluxes but couldn't get it to work. It's a few months ago now though so I can't remember exactly what the issue was. I'll update the issues that Nathan Goldbaum pointed out and re-submit the PR along with a test.

pullrequest.title: Adding Virial validation from Bleuler & Tessier (2014)

content.raw: @ngoldbaum Just looking at this now. The problem was that the "surf" object returned unitless arrays. I then had to add units so that everything made sense when these values were used in construction of other derived quantities otherwise YT rightly complained about unit inconsistencies.
content.html: Nathan Goldbaum Just looking at this now. The problem was that the "surf" object returned unitless arrays. I then had to add units so that everything made sense when these values were used in construction of other derived quantities otherwise YT rightly complained about unit inconsistencies.
